prompt.p: A 24-year-old man presents to his GP with generalized lethargy and weakness. He has no past medical history and denies any recreational drug use, gastrointestinal or genitourinary symptoms. On examination he appears relatively well although his blood pressure is 195/98 mmHg. His body mass index (BMI) is 24. Blood test results are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

modalFeedback.p: Option B (Conn's syndrome) is Correct. Hyperaldosteronism (Conn's syndrome) is associated with hypokalaemia and metabolic alkalosis.
Option A (Cirrhosis) is Incorrect. We would expect other clinical signs of this. Cirrhotics also tend to be hypotensive.
Option C (Cushing's disease) is Incorrect. Hypokalaemia and hypertension might occur but obesity, glucose intolerance and other clinical features of Cushing's would be expected.
Option D (Malnutrition) is Incorrect. This is possible but relatively unlikely. It would also not explain his extremely high blood pressure for his age group.
Option E (Small bowel fistula) is Incorrect. This is unlikely as we would expect other signs and gastrointestinal symptoms.
